lines.text: I tried to teach the rudiments of rugby football. But it wasn't really their sort of thing. They hang on to the ball for too long. Weeks, sometimes.
Most o' my boys just want company... a bit o' cheerin' up. I'm like a mother to 'em! Only they can't fuck their mothers so they come 'ere.
[On her husband's dying]
It was really a breach of manners. He's never done it before.
You can't miss it, sir. Turn right out of the station. Or left.
I once had a chap before me who'd been caught stealing from the mess. I ordered every alternate fingernail to be removed, and you know, I still get a card from him every Christmas.
You see, what I think is wrong with the country today is that there aren't enough people chained up.
[Writing to The Times on how to treat the poor]
Are there two "l"s in "disembowelment"?
Everyone was asking after you. They're all terribly excited about the wedding.
Wedding?
OUR wedding!
Oh, yes... Yes.
I shall be looking after women... Women who are in... moral trouble.
Liars?
Deborah, do you know what is meant by "fallen women"?
Women who have hurt their knees.
I'm going to remain a missionary.
But I thought...
A missionary IN ENGLAND!
But everyone's ENGLISH in England.
The locals had never seen a bicycle before. They used to call me "The Man on the Starving Horse."
Vicki...
Violet.
Er, Violet. Would you and Ruby...
Rosie.
Rosie. Go and clean upstairs, and get some help from the three girls in my bed.
[about Slatterthwaite]
He really is the most disastrous butler. Can't we get rid of him?
Of course we can't. He's been here for 25 years.
I don't know why we ever got rid of Marcheson.
You know perfectly well why we got rid of Marcheson.
That was only a bit of harmless fun.
Not for the parents.
Fetch the coaches, will you?
Oh, I love it when you give me orders.

[annoyed]
NOW!
Isabel?
Charles! What are you doing here?
I've come to stop you.
How dare you? How dare you interfere with my plans?
You mustn't kill him.
Why not? What business is it of yours, interfering priest?
You could hang for it.
No one's going to hang. It's a simple shooting accident.
Isabel, this is England in 1906. People don't go around killing each other just because they don't get on!
No, they just endure don't they? Stiff upper lip, that's the British way. I'm sure it wasn't like that in Africa.
Africa's primitive!
Oh, yes. God save us from being primitive.
There's not so much wrong with the British way, for your class especially.
My class? This is not my class, Charles.
You know what I mean.
You don't know what *I* mean.
[Adopts a changed accent and demeanor]
You alone, sir? Want some company? Clean and cheap?
[She returns to normal, Fortescue is speechless]
Yes. I've disguised it well, haven't I? I had to. The honest tart never gets anywhere. No, they're not my bloody class, thank God!
[Attempting to talk her out of a dangerous plan]
Isabel, I...
Please, don't. I don't want to be understood.
[pauses]
Not now.
What are you going to do? What are you going to gain from this?
[Isabel begins to say something, tearfully sighs, and walks out the door]
[Isabel has been injured]
I'm sorry. Dear, God, I'm so sorry.
You were only trying to do the decent thing.
[Fortescue begins to drape his coat around her]
No, don't Charles.
[He continues anyway]
That's the trouble with you. You're far too decent.
I got it all wrong, didn't I?
What do you mean?
I tried to convert the missionary.
